title: Even Trump's Biggest Fans on Wall Street Aren't Loving His Tariffs
snippets:
Even one of President Donald Trump's most vocal backers is wary of his tariff plan. 

Bill Ackman, the billionaire CEO of hedge fund Pershing Square and one of Trump's most fervent supporters on Wall Street, on Sunday criticized the president's "massive and disproportionate tariffs" on key U.S. trading partners and urged Trump to call a "90-day time out" to allow for negotiations. 

"Business is a confidence game. The president is losing the confidence of business leaders around the globe," Ackman posted to X on Sunday evening. "The consequences for our country and the millions of our citizens who have supported the president—in particular low-income consumers who are already under a huge amount of economic stress—are going to be severely negative. This is not what we voted for." 

'Economic Nuclear War'

Ackman equated Trump's reciprocal tariffs—including a 20% levy on imports from the European Union, 46% on Vietnamese goods, and 24% on Japanese products—with declaring "economic nuclear war on every country in the world," and warned the move would obstruct investment in the U.S. and cause lasting damage to America’s reputation on the world stage. 

In separate posts Sunday evening and Monday morning, Ackman placed blame for the tariff plans squarely on the president's advisors. "I just figured out why @howardlutnick is indifferent to the stock market and the economy crashing," he wrote late Sunday, referring to Commerce Secretary and former Cantor Fitzgerald CEO Howard Lutnick. "He and Cantor are long bonds. He profits when our economy implodes," Ackman wrote. 

National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett criticized Ackman on Fox News on Monday morning, saying, "I would urge everyone, especially Bill, to ease off the rhetoric a little bit. ... The idea that it's gonna be a 'nuclear winter' or something like that is completely irresponsible rhetoric."

Ackman Softens Lutnick Comments Monday

Ackman softened his comments on Lutnick Monday morning, writing that "It was unfair of me to lash out at @howardlutnick. I don't think he is pursuing his self interest… I am just frustrated watching what I believe to be a major policy error occur after our country and the president have been making huge economic progress that is now at risk due to the tariffs."

But Ackman continued to push back on the tariff plans. "The formula used by the administration to calculate tariffs made other nations’ tariffs appear four times larger than they actually are," he wrote Monday morning, citing research from the American Enterprise Institute, a right-leaning think tank. "The President's advisors need to acknowledge their error before April 9th and make a course correction before the President makes a big mistake based on bad math."
summary: Billionaire hedge fund CEO Bill Ackman, a prominent supporter of President Donald Trump, publicly criticized the president's tariff plans, describing them as "massive and disproportionate" and akin to declaring "economic nuclear war" on global trading partners. Ackman urged for a 90-day negotiation period and highlighted the negative impact on business confidence and low-income consumers in the U.S. He initially blamed Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick for the tariff strategy, suggesting a conflict of interest, but later softened his stance. Ackman also called out the administration's tariff c
titles: Even Trump's Biggest Fans on Wall Street Aren't Loving His Tariffs

title: The Cost of Your Car Tires Is Going to Go Up Because of Tariffs, JPMorgan Says
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Tire prices are likely to go up as a result of tariffs, JPMorgan analysts said.
  • Countries the U.S. imports tires from, including Thailand and Indonesia, are facing steep Trump administration tariffs.
  • Consumers may have some time before the full impact of the tariffs is felt, however, as companies stocked up on tires prior to the tariff announcement, the analysts said.


Tire prices are likely to increase as a result of the Trump administration's steep tariffs on countries that export them to the U.S., analysts at JPMorgan said Monday.

A record 63.4% of tires sold in the U.S. last year were imported, with Thailand (subject to a 37% tariff), Indonesia (32%), Vietnam (46%), and South Korea (26%) making up four of the top five countries the U.S. imports from, the analysts wrote.

"We expect U.S. tire prices to rise, perhaps substantially," JPMorgan said. Domestic tire producers should see a slight net benefit, but they face tariffs as well on the import of raw materials like rubber. Shares of Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT), which has operations in the U.S., Europe, and Asia, sank more than 7% intraday Monday. (Read Investopedia's live coverage of today's market action here.)

However, the full effect of price increases is "not likely to be felt immediately," the analysts wrote, since companies stocked up on imported tires before the tariffs were announced.
summary: Tire prices in the U.S. are expected to rise due to tariffs imposed by the Trump administration on countries like Thailand, Indonesia, Vietnam, and South Korea, which are major tire exporters to the U.S. JPMorgan analysts highlighted that these tariffs could substantially increase U.S. tire prices, though the immediate impact might be mitigated as companies have pre-stocked tires. The tariffs also affect domestic tire producers by increasing the cost of imported raw materials. This development led to a more than 7% drop in Goodyear Tire & Rubber's shares.
titles: The Cost of Your Car Tires Is Going to Go Up Because of Tariffs, JPMorgan Says

title: Andrew Bailey given top financial stability role as tariffs create turmoil

titles: Andrew Bailey given top financial stability role as tariffs create turmoil

title: 'Quantum Darwinism' may explain why we live in a shared reality
snippets: A framework inspired by evolution may demonstrate why two observers see the same non-quantum world emerge from the many fuzzy probabilities of the quantum realm
summary: A new framework inspired by evolutionary principles may explain why observers perceive the same non-quantum reality from the multitude of potential outcomes in the quantum realm. This approach suggests a unified way of understanding how consistent, observable phenomena arise from quantum probabilities.
titles: 'Quantum Darwinism' may explain why we live in a shared reality
